content: Irrigation has been crucial for the development and economy of the United States, especially in settling the West and revitalizing agriculture after the Dust Bowl. Technological advancements have modernized irrigated agriculture, but come with costs such as infrastructure and support programs. The costs of irrigation include infrastructure, support programs, and potential impacts on water users and the environment. Irrigation water use is measured by withdrawals and consumption, with consumption referring to water taken in by plants or evaporated without returning to water sources. Consumption from irrigation refers to water taken in by plants or evaporated without returning to water sources. Irrigation is the second-largest source of water withdrawals in the United States, but withdrawals have decreased by 23% since 1980. From 2005 to 2010, irrigation withdrawals dropped 9% nationally. It is uncertain if this decline in withdrawals has led to a decrease in water consumption due to improved irrigation efficiency. Since 2003, only four western states have seen an increase in irrigated acres, while the rest have seen a reduction. Several eastern states, on the other hand, have seen a significant increase in irrigated acres over this same time period; seven states increased irrigation by 50% (Delaware, Georgia, Illinois, Indiana, Mississippi, South Carolina, and Tennessee). Farmers shifted from gravity irrigation to pressurized sprinklers and microirrigation, especially in 17 western states. Since the 1980s, farmers in 17 western states have shifted from gravity irrigation to pressurized sprinklers and microirrigation. This led to a decline in gravity irrigation from almost 62% to 30% of irrigated acres by 2013. Irrigated land in the West increased by 1.7 million acres during this time, while applied irrigation water decreased by over 1.37 million acre-feet.
